Docs.summary: Provides an <see cref="T:System.Windows.Documents.AdornerLayer"> for the child elements in the visual tree.

remarks.format:
## Remarks AdornerDecorator can contain only one child element. That element can contain multiple elements that can be adorned.
The AdornerDecorator specifies the position of the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.AdornerLayer> in the visual tree. It is typically used in a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ControlTemplate> for a control that might host <xref:System.Windows.Documents.Adorner> objects. For example, the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ControlTemplate> of a <xref:System.Windows.Window> contains an AdornerDecorator so that the child elements of the window can be adorned. The <xref:System.Windows.Documents.AdornerLayer.GetAdornerLayer%2A> method returns `null` if you pass in an element that does not have an AdornerDecorator as an ancestor in its visual tree.
For more information about adorners and visual trees, see [Adorners Overview](../Topic/Adorners%20Overview.md) and [Trees in WPF](../Topic/Trees%20in%20WPF.md).
## Examples The following example creates a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ControlTemplate> for a <xref:System.Windows.Window>. The example adds a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContentPresenter> as the child element of an AdornerDecorator. The logical child elements of the window can be adorned because the AdornerDecorator is in their visual tree.
